Step 3: Once you have been approved for these new accounts, start making purchases or withdrawing money using the newly obtained credit cards. Be careful not to overspend as this may trigger fraud alerts from the issuing banks.

Step 4: Monitor your target victim's mail and email for any important documents or statements related to their financial accounts. This will help you stay one step ahead of them and avoid detection.

Step 5: After you have exhausted the funds on your new credit cards, it is time to close out these accounts. Do this by calling the customer service numbers provided in the account documentation.

Step 6: Now that you have closed out the fraudulent accounts, wait for a few months before attempting to apply for new ones in the target victim's name again. This will help ensure that your actions do not raise suspicion with credit bureaus or law enforcement agencies.
